page.title: 11THE BRENDON HILLS IRON MINES
page.content: To the north of this area are the remains of the iron mining industry that flourished in the Brendon Hill during the nineteenth century. This reached a peak in 1877 when over 52,000 tons of iron ore was taken by the now abandoned railway to the incline near Brendon Hill from where it was shipped to Ebbw Vale. About 100 of the miners lived in the hamlet of Gupworthy, now only a few cottages. Nonconformity and temperance alike flourished on the Brendons and there was a temperance hotel and Gupworthy had its own temperance society. After the Spanish Civil war the area declined and the railway was closed in 1898. It was reopened for two years in 1907 but was finally lifted during the First World War and used for scrap steel. (See Ralegh's Cross).
